title: Equestrian statue of Robert the Bruce, Bannockburn
text:
The equestrian statue of Robert the Bruce at the <a href="Bannockburn%20Visitor%20Centre">Bannockburn Visitor Centre</a>, <a href="Bannockburn">Bannockburn</a>, <a href="Stirling">Stirling</a>, is a 1964 work by <a href="Pilkington%20Jackson">Pilkington Jackson</a>.
Description.
The bronze sculpture depicts <a href="Robert%20the%20Bruce">Robert the Bruce</a> wielding an axe and on a <a href="war%20horse">war horse</a>. The statue stands on a <a href="plinth">plinth</a> that bears the inscription "ROBERT THE BRUCE 
KING OF SCOTS 1306-1329". It is located near the site of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bannockburn">Battle of Bannockburn</a>. The statue is a <a href="Listed%20buildings%20in%20Scotland">A listed building</a>.
History.
The statue was commissioned by the <a href="Edward%20Bruce%2C%2010th%20Earl%20of%20Elgin">Earl of Elgin</a> in 1964 to commemorate the 650th anniversary of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bannockburn">Battle of Bannockburn</a>. It was sculpted by <a href="Pilkington%20Jackson">Pilkington Jackson</a> using the measurements of Bruce's skull, re-discovered at <a href="Dunfermline%20Abbey">Dunfermline Abbey</a> in 1818. The statue was unveiled by <a href="Elizabeth%20II">the Queen</a>.
In 1966, a replica of the statue was placed outside the <a href="Alberta%20University%20of%20the%20Arts">Alberta University of the Arts</a> in <a href="Calgary">Calgary</a>, <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. The statue was funded by Canadian lawyer <a href="Eric%20Harvie">Eric Harvie</a>.
From 2009 to 2020, the statue featured on the <a href="Clydesdale%20Bank%20%C2%A320%20note">Clydesdale Bank £20 note</a>.
In 2013, the statue was restored in preparation for the 700th anniversary of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bannockburn">Battle of Bannockburn</a> in 2014. The statue which was cast in bronze was slowly turning <a href="Verdigris">green</a>. <a href="Cabinet%20Secretary%20for%20Economy%2C%20Fair%20Work%20and%20Culture">Culture secretary</a> <a href="Fiona%20Hyslop">Fiona Hyslop</a> said "The Robert the Bruce statue is an iconic part of the Bannockburn site, and a poignant reminder of the battle".
On 11 June 2020, following the <a href="actions%20against%20memorials%20in%20Great%20Britain%20during%20the%20George%20Floyd%20protests">actions against memorials in Great Britain during the George Floyd protests</a>, the statue was defaced with graffiti. The Scottish king was branded as a racist, despite not being involved in the <a href="slave%20trade">slave trade</a>. <a href="Stirling%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Stirling</a> MP <a href="Alyn%20Smith">Alyn Smith</a> said “I’ve been vocal in my support of <a href="Black%20Lives%20Matter">#BlackLivesMatter</a> and hope such counterproductive stupidity is an isolated incident.”
